column1: Lpez-Alegra was born in Madrid, Spain and raised in Mission Viejo, California.
A natural leader, he was the top Lieutenant of 60 in the second largest aviation wardroom in the Navy (105 officers).
He was one of the few EP-3E pilots in the squadron to get flying time in the EA-3B Skywarrior.
He is a graduate of Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government Program for Senior Executives in National and International Security.
He is fluent in English, Spanish, French and Russian.

column2: His son Nicolas starred alongside Lpez-Alegra in 2006 in Mira La Luna (directed by Eduard Bosch).

column1: A second documentary, directed by Manuel Huerga, Son And Moon, was released in Spanish theaters in 2009 featuring astronauts Mikhail Tyurin, Sunita Williams and himself.
During flight STS-92, he tested the SAFER jet backpack with fellow astronaut Jeff Wisoff, flying up to 50 feet from the spacecraft.
Lpez-Alegra served as an aquanaut on the first NEEMO (NASA Extreme Environment Mission Operations) crew aboard the Aquarius underwater laboratory in October 2001.
On Expedition 14, he performed five spacewalks.

column2: On 21 April 2007 he undocked from the ISS and returned to Earth.

column1: Lpez-Alegra holds the all time American record for number of EVAs (10) and total EVA duration (67 hours and 40 minutes).
The previous record holder, Jerry L. Ross had a total of 9 EVAs with a duration of 58 hours and 18 minutes.
Lpez-Alegra is the second most experienced spacewalker overall, behind Russia's Anatoly Solovyev.
On April 2, 2007, Lpez-Alegra set the record for the longest space mission of any American astronaut.
When he landed on April 21, his time in space on a single mission was 215 days.
(The longest space mission on record is that of Valeriy Polyakov, who spent 437 days aboard the Russian space station Mir in 1994 and 1995.)
On October 19, 2007, Lpez-Alegra visited his old high school Mission Viejo High School, where he told the students about his space travel expedition.

column2: Lpez-Alegra currently serves as Flight Crew Operations Directorate Assistant Director for ISS.

column1: At the end of his mission, he commanded the longest flight by a Soyuz spacecraft, making Expedition 14 the longest expedition thus far.

column2: Lpez-Alegra broke the record for longest spaceflight by an American astronaut.

column1: Lpez-Alegra retired from NASA on March 12, 2012 to become President of the Commercial Spaceflight Federation.

column2: This article incorporatespublic domain material from websites or documents of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
